acne.myth: Popping pimples makes them heal faster
acne.fact: Popping pimples can worsen acne and cause scarring or infection. Dermatologists recommend avoiding this.

acne.myth: Toothpaste is an effective acne treatment
acne.fact: Toothpaste is not designed for skin and can cause irritation or worsen acne.
Over-washing or using harsh cleansers can irritate skin and worsen acne. Gentle cleansing is safest.
Sun exposure can increase irritation and long-term damage. It doesn’t clear acne.

acne.myth: Chocolate and greasy food cause acne
acne.fact: No scientific proof links chocolate or greasy foods directly to acne, though high-glycemic diets may worsen acne for some individuals.
Home remedies like lemon juice, salt water, or toothpaste lack scientific backing and may irritate or damage skin.
Adults also get acne, and it may persist for years without proper treatment.
Non-comedogenic makeup is safe for acne-prone skin, but makeup cannot cure acne.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Poor facial hygiene causes acne or is the main cause of acne
acne_vulgaris.fact: Acne vulgaris is driven by blocked follicles, excess sebum, bacteria, and inflammation—not simply dirt or poor hygiene.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Acne is just a teenage problem that will go away on its own
acne_vulgaris.fact: Acne vulgaris can persist into adulthood, especially in women, and leaving it untreated can lead to scarring.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Eating greasy food, chocolate, or dairy always causes acne
acne_vulgaris.fact: Diet may influence acne vulgaris in some people, but there is no universal direct cause-and-effect relationship.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Drinking lots of water will clear acne
acne_vulgaris.fact: Hydration is healthy but is not a cure or treatment for acne vulgaris.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Tanning or strong sun exposure clears acne
acne_vulgaris.fact: Sun exposure may temporarily reduce redness but leads to irritation, hyperpigmentation, and long-term skin damage.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Using a lot of makeup always causes acne
acne_vulgaris.fact: Non-comedogenic, oil-free makeup does not cause acne when removed properly.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Popping or squeezing pimples helps them heal faster
acne_vulgaris.fact: Popping causes deeper inflammation, infection risk, and scarring.
Acne vulgaris is not infectious and cannot spread from person to person.

acne_vulgaris.myth: Only topical creams are needed to cure acne quickly
acne_vulgaris.fact: Acne vulgaris often requires combination treatment—topical products, medication, lifestyle changes—and improvement takes time.

pemphigus.myth: Pemphigus goes into remission during pregnancy and does not require treatment
pemphigus.fact: Pregnancy can trigger new onset pemphigus or cause disease relapse, requiring close monitoring and treatment to prevent adverse maternal and fetal outcomes.

pemphigus.myth: All immunosuppressive drugs used for pemphigus are safe during pregnancy
pemphigus.fact: Several common pemphigus treatments—such as methotrexate, mycophenolate mofetil, and cyclophosphamide—are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic risk.

pemphigus.myth: Neonatal pemphigus is caused by genetic inheritance from the mother
pemphigus.fact: Neonatal pemphigus results from passive transplacental transfer of maternal autoantibodies and usually resolves spontaneously within 1–4 weeks.

pemphigus.myth: Pregnant patients with pemphigus should stop all medications to protect the baby
pemphigus.fact: Stopping treatment can worsen maternal disease and harm both mother and fetus. Safe options like low-dose corticosteroids, azathioprine, and IVIg can be used under supervision.

pemphigus.myth: Azathioprine should never be used during pregnancy
pemphigus.fact: Newer evidence shows azathioprine is compatible with pregnancy and is conditionally recommended by the American College of Rheumatology.

pemphigus.myth: Breastfeeding is unsafe for mothers with pemphigus
pemphigus.fact: Many treatments for pemphigus—including corticosteroids, azathioprine, and IVIg—are compatible with breastfeeding when properly timed and monitored.

pemphigoid_gestationis.myth: Pemphigoid gestationis always resolves after delivery with no risk of recurrence
pemphigoid_gestationis.fact: PG often recurs postpartum, during menses, or with hormonal contraceptives, and may persist or follow a chronic-relapsing course.

pemphigoid_gestationis.myth: Mild PG does not require treatment because it is harmless
pemphigoid_gestationis.fact: PG can cause significant pruritus and blistering, and untreated disease may worsen. High-potency topical steroids are recommended even for mild cases.

pemphigoid_gestationis.myth: Systemic corticosteroids are too dangerous to use in pregnancy
pemphigoid_gestationis.fact: Systemic corticosteroids are a first-line therapy for moderate-to-severe PG and are considered safe when appropriately monitored.

pemphigoid_gestationis.myth: IVIg and dapsone are unsafe for treating PG in pregnancy
pemphigoid_gestationis.fact: Both IVIg and dapsone have been successfully used as steroid-sparing agents in pregnancy and are acceptable options for selected cases.

pemphigoid_gestationis.myth: Breastfeeding is not allowed for mothers treated for PG
pemphigoid_gestationis.fact: Many PG therapies—including systemic corticosteroids, IVIg, and some TNF-α inhibitors—are compatible with breastfeeding.

pemphigoid_gestationis.myth: PG is caused by herpes infection because it was historically called 'herpes gestationis'
pemphigoid_gestationis.fact: PG is not caused by herpes virus; it is an autoimmune blistering disease targeting basement membrane proteins.

acrodermatitis_enteropathica.myth: Topical zinc creams or a zinc-rich diet alone can fully treat the condition
acrodermatitis_enteropathica.fact: Oral zinc sulfate is the only effective treatment; topical zinc is ineffective due to poor absorption in acrodermatitis enteropathica.

acrodermatitis_enteropathica.myth: It’s just a rash that will go away with moisturizers
acrodermatitis_enteropathica.fact: It is a genetic disorder of zinc malabsorption requiring lifelong oral zinc supplementation to prevent systemic complications.

actinic_keratosis.myth: Lemon juice or apple cider vinegar can safely remove actinic keratoses
actinic_keratosis.fact: No evidence supports natural acids; field therapies like 5-FU, imiquimod, or cryotherapy are standard and prevent progression to squamous cell carcinoma.

actinic_keratosis.myth: Sunscreen alone will make existing AK lesions disappear
actinic_keratosis.fact: Sunscreen prevents new lesions but does not treat existing ones; medical intervention is required.

allergic_contact_dermatitis.myth: Essential oils like tea tree or lavender heal allergic contact dermatitis
allergic_contact_dermatitis.fact: They may worsen sensitization; strict allergen avoidance plus topical corticosteroids are evidence-based.

allergic_contact_dermatitis.myth: Over-the-counter hydrocortisone is enough for severe cases
allergic_contact_dermatitis.fact: Patch testing to identify the allergen and potent prescription steroids or tacrolimus are often needed.

aplasia_cutis.myth: Vitamin E oil or honey speeds healing and prevents scarring
aplasia_cutis.fact: Conservative management with gentle cleansing and dressings is standard; no role for unproven topicals.
Most cases heal with conservative wound care; surgery is reserved for large defects or complications.

basal_cell_carcinoma.myth: Black salve or bloodroot paste can cure BCC without surgery
basal_cell_carcinoma.fact: These cause mutilation and incomplete removal; Mohs surgery, excision, or radiation are the only proven treatments.

basal_cell_carcinoma.myth: BCC never metastasizes, so treatment can be delayed
basal_cell_carcinoma.fact: Though metastasis is rare (<0.5%), local invasion causes significant morbidity; prompt treatment is essential.

basal_cell_carcinoma_morpheiform.myth: Cryotherapy is sufficient for morpheaform BCC
basal_cell_carcinoma_morpheiform.fact: High recurrence rate due to subclinical extension; Mohs micrographic surgery is required for clear margins.

basal_cell_carcinoma_morpheiform.myth: It behaves like typical nodular BCC
basal_cell_carcinoma_morpheiform.fact: Morpheaform BCC is more aggressive with infiltrative growth; standard excision has higher failure rates.

becker_nevus.myth: Laser treatment permanently removes the pigmentation
becker_nevus.fact: Recurrence is common; Q-switched lasers provide inconsistent, temporary improvement.

becker_nevus.myth: It will fade completely with age
becker_nevus.fact: Hyperpigmentation and hair persist lifelong; treatment is cosmetic only.

behcets_disease.myth: Colchicine alone controls all mucocutaneous lesions long-term
behcets_disease.fact: Apremilast, azathioprine, or biologics are needed in refractory cases per EULAR guidelines.
Behçet’s is a systemic vasculitis; ocular, vascular, and neurologic involvement requires multidisciplinary care.

calcinosis_cutis.myth: Vitamin K cream or aluminum hydroxide dissolves calcium deposits
calcinosis_cutis.fact: No evidence supports these; surgical excision or diltiazem has limited efficacy in systemic sclerosis–associated cases.
Persistent in connective tissue diseases; medical management targets underlying inflammation.

cheilitis.myth: Coconut oil or lip balm cures angular cheilitis
cheilitis.fact: Treat the underlying cause (fungal, bacterial, or nutritional); oils may worsen occlusion and infection.

cheilitis.myth: It’s always due to vitamin deficiency
cheilitis.fact: Common causes include Candida, Staphylococcus, or denture-related trauma; labs guide therapy.

congenital_nevus.myth: Early prophylactic excision prevents melanoma in all congenital nevi
congenital_nevus.fact: Lifetime risk is low (<1% for small/medium); observation with dermoscopy is often preferred over routine removal.
Risk correlates with size; giant nevi (>20 cm) warrant closer monitoring and possible staged excision.

dariers_disease.myth: High-dose vitamin A or topical retinoids cure the genetic defect
dariers_disease.fact: Systemic retinoids (acitretin, isotretinoin) control symptoms but do not cure the ATP2A2 mutation.

dariers_disease.myth: Avoiding heat and sweat prevents all flares
dariers_disease.fact: Triggers exacerbate but do not cause the disease; retinoids are mainstay therapy.

dermatofibroma.myth: Tea tree oil or castor oil makes dermatofibromas shrink or vanish
dermatofibroma.fact: Benign fibrous tumors; excision if symptomatic or cosmetically bothersome; no topical cure exists.
Reactive hyperplasia, often post-trauma; no infectious etiology.

dermatomyositis.myth: IVIG is first-line therapy for all patients
dermatomyositis.fact: Corticosteroids plus immunosuppressants (methotrexate, azathioprine) are initial; IVIG is reserved for refractory cases.

dermatomyositis.myth: Skin findings resolve with sun protection alone
dermatomyositis.fact: Antimalarials and systemic therapy are required; malignancy screening is mandatory.

disseminated_actinic_porokeratosis.myth: Cryotherapy permanently cures disseminated actinic porokeratosis
disseminated_actinic_porokeratosis.fact: High recurrence; topical 5-FU, imiquimod, or diclofenac are preferred for field treatment.

disseminated_actinic_porokeratosis.myth: It’s harmless and never turns cancerous
disseminated_actinic_porokeratosis.fact: Small but real risk of squamous cell carcinoma; regular surveillance is needed.

drug_eruption.myth: Antihistamines alone treat severe reactions like SJS/TEN
drug_eruption.fact: Immediate drug cessation and supportive care are critical; cyclosporine may shorten duration in TEN.

drug_eruption.myth: Mild rashes always resolve without stopping the drug
drug_eruption.fact: Cross-reactivity and progression risk necessitate discontinuation and allergy documentation.

drug_induced_pigmentary_changes.fact: Minocycline, amiodarone, and antimalarial pigmentation are often permanent; sun protection is key.

drug_induced_pigmentary_changes.myth: It always fades after stopping the drug
drug_induced_pigmentary_changes.fact: Dermal melanin or iron deposits (e.g., minocycline) persist indefinitely in many cases.

dyshidrotic_eczema.myth: Botox injections provide a permanent cure
dyshidrotic_eczema.fact: Temporary symptom relief; topical corticosteroids, calcineurin inhibitors, and trigger avoidance are first-line.
Idiopathic or allergic; hyperhidrosis is a trigger, not the cause.

eczema.myth: Oatmeal baths or coconut oil replace medical treatment
eczema.fact: Adjuncts only; emollients, topical steroids, or calcineurin inhibitors are essential per AAD guidelines.

eczema.myth: Dietary elimination cures atopic dermatitis in most adults
eczema.fact: Food triggers are relevant in <10% of adults; patch testing identifies contact allergens.

ehlers_danlos_syndrome.myth: Collagen supplements strengthen skin and prevent bruising
ehlers_danlos_syndrome.fact: Genetic defect in collagen synthesis; no evidence supports oral collagen efficacy.

ehlers_danlos_syndrome.myth: It’s just hypermobility that needs stretching
ehlers_danlos_syndrome.fact: Multisystem connective tissue disorder; physical therapy focuses on stability, not flexibility.

epidermal_nevus.myth: Topical retinoids or keratolytics remove epidermal nevi
epidermal_nevus.fact: Surgical excision or ablation is required; topicals are ineffective for full-thickness lesions.

epidermal_nevus.myth: They always require removal to prevent cancer
epidermal_nevus.fact: Benign; excision is cosmetic or if inflamed; malignancy risk is negligible.

epidermolysis_bullosa.myth: Gene therapy is widely available for all EB types
epidermolysis_bullosa.fact: Only FDA-approved for recessive dystrophic EB (beremagene geperpavec); most require meticulous wound care.
Non-adherent dressings and culture-guided antibiotics are standard; silver agents may delay healing.

erythema_annulare_centrifugum.fact: Often paraneoplastic or idiopathic; treat underlying malignancy, infection, or use topical steroids.

erythema_annulare_centrifugum.myth: It’s always a harmless annular rash
erythema_annulare_centrifugum.fact: Workup for malignancy, infection, or connective tissue disease is mandatory.

erythema_elevatum_diutinum.fact: Controls neutrophilic inflammation but lesions recur upon cessation; no cure exists.
Associated with hematologic disorders or infections; long-term monitoring is required.

erythema_multiforme.myth: Systemic steroids prevent recurrence in HSV-associated EM
erythema_multiforme.fact: Supportive care; prophylactic acyclovir reduces HSV-triggered episodes, not steroids.

erythema_multiforme.myth: It’s the same as Stevens-Johnson syndrome
erythema_multiforme.fact: EM major involves mucosal target lesions; SJS/TEN is a distinct spectrum with higher mortality.

erythema_nodosum.myth: NSAIDs alone are sufficient for all cases
erythema_nodosum.fact: Treat underlying cause (streptococcal infection, sarcoidosis); potassium iodide or colchicine for idiopathic.

erythema_nodosum.myth: It’s a sign of deep vein thrombosis
erythema_nodosum.fact: Painful panniculitis; DVT presents with unilateral calf swelling and requires anticoagulation.

factitial_dermatitis.myth: Strong topical steroids heal self-inflicted wounds quickly
factitial_dermatitis.fact: Psychiatric evaluation and therapy are essential; dermatologic care is secondary and supportive.
Patients bypass dressings; behavioral interventions address the root cause.

fixed_eruptions.myth: Patch testing reliably identifies the culprit drug
fixed_eruptions.fact: Oral provocation is safer and more sensitive; patch tests are often negative in fixed drug eruption.

fixed_eruptions.myth: It resolves permanently after one episode
fixed_eruptions.fact: Recurs at the same site upon re-exposure; strict drug avoidance is lifelong.

folliculitis.myth: Tea tree oil cures bacterial folliculitis
folliculitis.fact: May irritate; culture-guided topical (mupirocin) or oral antibiotics (doxycycline) are needed.
Staphylococcus, Pseudomonas (hot tub), or fungal etiologies require specific therapy.

fordyce_spots.fact: Ectopic sebaceous glands; cosmetic only—no medical treatment required or effective.
Normal anatomic variant present in up to 80% of adults.

granuloma_annulare.myth: Biologic agents are first-line for localized GA
granuloma_annulare.fact: Self-limited in most cases; intralesional or topical steroids, cryotherapy suffice.
Association is weak; glucose testing is not routinely required.

granuloma_pyogenic.myth: Silver nitrate cauterization provides a permanent cure
granuloma_pyogenic.fact: High recurrence; curettage with electrodesiccation or full excision with histology is preferred.
Lobular capillary hemangioma; bacterial infection is secondary.

hailey_hailey_disease.fact: ATP2C1 genetic defect; topical corticosteroids, naltrexone, or botulinum toxin for refractory cases.
Heat, friction, and sweating exacerbate; sun protection and moisture control are key.

halo_nevus.myth: Excision is mandatory to prevent melanoma
halo_nevus.fact: Benign immune-mediated depigmentation; observation or biopsy only if central nevus is atypical.
Repigmentation is rare; vitiligo-like depigmentation may persist.

hidradenitis.fact: Chronic inflammatory disease; adalimumab (anti-TNF) is first-line biologic for moderate-severe HS.

hidradenitis.myth: It’s just recurrent boils from poor hygiene
hidradenitis.fact: Follicular occlusion and immune dysregulation; weight loss and smoking cessation improve outcomes.

ichthyosis_vulgaris.myth: Fish oil supplements cure the scaling
ichthyosis_vulgaris.fact: FLG gene mutation; emollients, keratolytics (urea, lactic acid) manage symptoms only.
Lifelong; severity may decrease but scaling persists.

incontinentia_pigmenti.myth: Laser therapy treats the skin lesions effectively
incontinentia_pigmenti.fact: Self-resolving in stages; monitor neurologic, ocular, and dental complications.

incontinentia_pigmenti.myth: Skin findings are the only concern
incontinentia_pigmenti.fact: X-linked dominant; CNS seizures and retinal detachment require multidisciplinary care.

juvenile_xanthogranuloma.myth: Systemic steroids shrink all JXG lesions
juvenile_xanthogranuloma.fact: Self-limited in >90%; observation preferred; excision only if symptomatic.
Benign histiocytic proliferation; systemic JXG may involve eye or liver.

kaposi_sarcoma.myth: HAART alone cures all forms of Kaposi sarcoma
kaposi_sarcoma.fact: May regress iatrogenic KS but classic or endemic often need chemotherapy or radiation.
HHV-8 driven; occurs in transplant recipients and elderly Mediterranean men.

keloid.myth: Vitamin E oil or cream prevents keloid formation
keloid.fact: No evidence; intralesional triamcinolone, silicone sheeting, and 5-FU are guideline-recommended.
Combination therapy (steroids, radiation, laser) is required for reduction.

keratosis_pilaris.myth: Aggressive exfoliation or scrubbing cures KP
keratosis_pilaris.fact: Genetic follicular hyperkeratosis; lactic acid, urea, or salicylic acid improve but do not cure.

keratosis_pilaris.myth: It’s a sign of vitamin deficiency

langerhans_cell_histiocytosis.myth: Steroids alone are sufficient for multisystem LCH
langerhans_cell_histiocytosis.fact: Vinblastine + prednisone is standard; BRAF inhibitors (vemurafenib) for mutated cases.
Requires staging; bone, pituitary, and lung involvement common.

lentigo_maligna.fact: High recurrence rate; staged excision or Mohs surgery is gold standard.
Melanoma in situ on sun-damaged skin; progression to invasive melanoma possible.

lichen_amyloidosis.myth: Potent topical steroids cure the pruritic papules
lichen_amyloidosis.fact: Symptomatic relief only; acitretin, phototherapy, or capsaicin for chronic itching.
Deposition of keratin-derived amyloid from chronic friction; not infectious.

lichen_planus.myth: Antiseptic mouthwash resolves oral lichen planus
lichen_planus.fact: Topical/oral corticosteroids; monitor for squamous cell carcinoma risk.

lichen_planus.myth: It always resolves within a year
lichen_planus.fact: Cutaneous LP self-limits; oral and hypertrophic variants may persist decades.

lichen_simplex.myth: Oral antihistamines stop the itch-scratch cycle
lichen_simplex.fact: Potent topical steroids under occlusion break the cycle; antihistamines are adjunctive.
Neurogenic inflammation; habit reversal and stress management help but are not curative.

livedo_reticularis.myth: Aspirin or blood thinners treat physiologic livedo
livedo_reticularis.fact: Benign vasospasm; treat underlying cause (e.g., vasculitis, thrombophilia) if pathologic.

livedo_reticularis.myth: It’s always a sign of serious clotting disorder
livedo_reticularis.fact: Physiologic in cold exposure; workup only if persistent or associated symptoms.

psoriasis.myth: Herbal therapies like Aloe Vera or St. John’s Wort cure psoriasis
psoriasis.fact: Due to lack of evidence or conflicting studies, guidelines do not recommend these agents; prescription treatments like topicals, phototherapy, or biologics are standard.

psoriasis.myth: Tazarotene is safe for genital psoriasis
psoriasis.fact: Tazarotene irritates the genital area and can worsen psoriasis; use dermatologist-prescribed treatments specifically for this sensitive region.

pustular_psoriasis.myth: Topical treatments alone control generalized pustular psoriasis
pustular_psoriasis.fact: Systemic therapies like cyclosporine or biologics (e.g., spesolimab) are required for moderate to severe cases; topicals are adjunctive.

pustular_psoriasis.myth: Systemic corticosteroids are safe for pustular psoriasis
pustular_psoriasis.fact: Corticosteroids can trigger flares and should be avoided; use targeted immunomodulators instead.

pyogenic_granuloma.myth: Table salt or home remedies provide a permanent cure
pyogenic_granuloma.fact: High recurrence with salt; surgical excision or curettage with electrodesiccation is preferred for low recurrence.
Rare association; most are idiopathic or post-trauma; monitor but do not discontinue retinoids unnecessarily.

rhinophyma.myth: Alcohol causes rhinophyma and abstaining cures it
rhinophyma.fact: No proven connection; rhinophyma is due to rosacea progression, treated with laser or surgery.
Occurs in rosacea patients regardless of alcohol use; early rosacea management prevents progression.

rosacea.myth: Rosacea is contagious or due to poor hygiene
rosacea.fact: Chronic inflammatory disorder; treated with metronidazole or laser, not hygiene alone.
Rosacea-friendly moisturizers improve treatment outcomes by reducing dryness and irritation.

sarcoidosis.fact: No long-term evidence; antimalarials or systemic therapies treat skin involvement.

sarcoidosis.myth: Sarcoidosis on skin always needs treatment
sarcoidosis.fact: Many cases resolve spontaneously; treat if symptomatic or affecting organs.

scabies.fact: Prescription scabicides like permethrin are required; OTC does not kill mites.
Animal mites cause temporary irritation but not human scabies; treat humans only.

scleroderma.fact: No evidence; focus on moisturizing, avoiding injury, and systemic therapies.
Avoid tattoos; they injure skin and risk calcium deposit complications.

scleromyxedema.fact: No consensus; intravenous immunoglobulin is effective and safe for systemic involvement.
Chronic; treatments like IVIG control symptoms but do not cure.

seborrheic_dermatitis.myth: Harsh shampoos or vinegar cure seborrheic dermatitis
seborrheic_dermatitis.fact: Harsh products worsen it; medicated shampoos with antifungals are essential.
Yeast overgrowth on oily skin; not contagious or hygiene-related.

seborrheic_keratosis.myth: Apple cider vinegar removes seborrheic keratoses
seborrheic_keratosis.fact: No proven home remedies; cryotherapy or excision if bothersome.
Harmless; removal is cosmetic unless irritated.

solid_cystic_basal_cell_carcinoma.myth: Natural remedies like black salve treat cystic BCC
solid_cystic_basal_cell_carcinoma.fact: Black salve mutilates; Mohs surgery is standard for cure.
Rare metastasis but local invasion requires prompt surgical removal.

squamous_cell_carcinoma.fact: Surgery or radiation; no evidence for non-standard remedies.

squamous_cell_carcinoma.myth: Black salve is safe for SCC
squamous_cell_carcinoma.fact: Causes severe damage; excision prevents recurrence.

stasis_edema.myth: Herbal soaks alone treat stasis dermatitis
stasis_edema.fact: Compression and moisturizers essential; herbs lack evidence.
Venous insufficiency worsens without compression therapy.

stevens_johnson_syndrome.fact: Stop causative drug and provide supportive care; antihistamines ineffective for severe cases.
Life-threatening; requires hospitalization, not outpatient allergy management.

striae.myth: Cocoa butter prevents or cures stretch marks
striae.fact: Studies show no benefit; tretinoin may help early striae.
White striae are permanent; laser can improve appearance.

sun_damaged_skin.fact: Tanning worsens damage; daily sun protection and retinoids treat signs.
Prevents further damage; procedures like lasers needed for reversal.

superficial_spreading_melanoma.myth: Indoor tanning provides a safe base tan
superficial_spreading_melanoma.fact: Increases melanoma risk; no safe tan exists.
Immunotherapy or surgery required; alternatives like laetrile are ineffective.

syringoma.myth: Lemon juice or aloe vera removes syringomas
syringoma.fact: No evidence; electrosurgery or laser preferred for removal.
Temporary pruritus relief; surgical options for permanent removal.

telangiectases.fact: OTC ineffective; laser therapy is standard.
Often benign; workup if symptomatic or patterned.

tick_bite.myth: Burning or petroleum jelly removes ticks safely
tick_bite.fact: Increases infection risk; use tweezers for prompt removal.

tick_bite.myth: Wait to see a doctor after a tick bite
tick_bite.fact: Remove immediately; monitor for symptoms and seek care if rash or fever develops.

tuberous_sclerosis.fact: No cure; mTOR inhibitors like sirolimus manage symptoms.

tuberous_sclerosis.myth: Skin lesions are the only concern
tuberous_sclerosis.fact: Multisystem; monitor for neurologic, cardiac involvement.

tungiasis.myth: Self-removal with sharp objects cures tungiasis
tungiasis.fact: Risks infection; surgical extraction by professional recommended.
Leads to secondary infections; remove flea and treat wounds.

urticaria.fact: No strong evidence; second-generation antihistamines are first-line.
Often idiopathic; evaluation for triggers but many spontaneous.

urticaria_pigmentosa.myth: Topical steroids alone treat urticaria pigmentosa
urticaria_pigmentosa.fact: Phototherapy or systemic agents for extensive cases; observation for mild.

vitiligo.myth: Ginkgo biloba or herbal remedies cure vitiligo
vitiligo.fact: Limited evidence; topical tacrolimus or phototherapy preferred.
Autoimmune; increases risk of other autoimmune diseases like thyroiditis.

xanthomas.fact: No evidence; treat underlying hyperlipidemia for resolution.
Sign of lipid disorder; excision recurs without addressing cause.

xeroderma_pigmentosum.myth: Sunscreens alone prevent all damage in XP
xeroderma_pigmentosum.fact: Strict UV avoidance essential; no cure, focus on total protection.
Even brief exposure causes burns and cancer; lifelong precautions needed.

benign_keratosis.fact: Benign growths; cryotherapy if cosmetic concern, no topical cure.
Harmless like seborrheic keratoses; monitor for changes.

melanocytic_nevus.fact: Risks recurrence or missing atypia; excision if suspicious.
Benign; use ABCDE criteria for excision decisions.

vascular_lesion.fact: Some require beta-blockers or laser; monitor closely.
Persist and darken; early pulsed-dye laser best.
